data.text: @Alice_comfy Senko will deal with this https://t.co/ka5KatTGrS

@ichimikichiki @0xripebanana @ByzGeneral Alternatively on the psychosomatic theory, it's possible that the real effect then becomes some form of learned helplessness which prevents recovery.

This is similar to the mechanism for which short term insomnia causes long term insomnia.

@ichimikichiki @0xripebanana @ByzGeneral I can say anecdotally 5 days into active infection, mentally I'm mostly back to normal now (just woke up). Yesterday a bit impaired, and the day before I couldn't follow anything. 

I could believe in more severe cases if the oxygen deprivation was really bad that could do it.

@Alice_comfy @0xripebanana @ByzGeneral No that doesn't make much sense.
Have heard one scientist mention that they think the virus hides in places where the immune system does not reach.

@ichimikichiki @0xripebanana @ByzGeneral The point I was making, was regarding anecdotal reports of long covid survivor's having immediate reduction in symptoms from the vaccine, which would not make sense with a physiological cause.

@ichimikichiki @0xripebanana @ByzGeneral I think it was fairly good pre Omicron and only useful against severe disease now. Post infection immunity seems to be better. 

Efficacy against infection long term is not possible similar to influenza.
@Alice_comfy @0xripebanana @ByzGeneral Honestly I don't think the vaccine appears to be very effective at all.

@0xripebanana @ichimikichiki @ByzGeneral But the idea it's anywhere near 10% or 30% as some of these Long Covid zealots claim doesn't add up.

A pretty good thread on the first brain study. https://t.co/C9gVOgiH1f

@0xripebanana @ichimikichiki @ByzGeneral I have also heard reports for some people that receiving a single dose of vaccine has a dramatic effect on this illness. 

To me that seems impossible without a psychosomatic cause. It can be a combination, I can believe that some people do get awful effects.
